abstract.text: Optimize a texture’s data to improve GPU or CPU access.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: By default, Metal attempts to optimize a texture’s data for both GPU or CPU accesses based on the texture’s storage mode and usage options. You can improve a texture’s performance on the GPU or CPU by specifically optimizing the texture’s data for either use case. You can also opt out of optimization altogether. Optimizing a texture’s performance for one use can decrease that texture’s performance for another.
Before optimizing texture data, carefully consider the storage modes and usage options for your textures. For guidance on resource storage modes, see
. For guidance on texture usage options, see
Metal may not be able to optimize some textures for specific hardware and ignores optimization API calls for those textures.

content.text: Optimize Texture Data for GPU Access

inlineContent.text: By default, Metal attempts to optimize texture data for GPU access if it meets any of these conditions:
You create the texture with an
mode.
You create the texture with an
option.
If the texture doesn’t meet any of these conditions,
you can optimize your texture data explicitly.
After you create your texture and populate its contents, encode and commit an
or
command.

code: // Create a command buffer to submit work to the GPU.
// Optimize the texture for GPU access by encoding a blit command.
// Texture 1 is optimized for CPU access.
// Commit the command buffer to the command queue.
// Create a command buffer to submit work to the GPU.
// Optimize the texture for GPU access by encoding a blit command.
// Texture 1 is optimized for CPU access.
// Commit the command buffer to the command queue.

content.text: Optimize Texture Data for CPU Access

inlineContent.text: By default, Metal attempts to optimize texture data for CPU access if it meets both of these conditions:
You create the texture with an
or
mode.
You write to the texture with the
or
method.
If you don’t meet both of these conditions, you can optimize your texture data explicitly. After you create your texture and populate its contents, encode and commit an
or
command.

code: // Create a command buffer to submit work to the GPU.
// Optimize the texture for CPU access by encoding a blit command.
// End encoding and commit it to the command buffer with add a completion handler.
// Texture 2 is optimized for CPU access.
// Commit the command buffer to the command queue.
// Create a command buffer to submit work to the GPU.
// Optimize the texture for CPU access by encoding a blit command.
// End encoding and commit it to the command buffer with add a completion handler.
// Texture 2 is optimized for CPU access.
// Commit the command buffer to the command queue.

content.text: Apply Lossless Compression to a Texture on Apple GPUs

inlineContent.text: Lossless compression is a specific form of GPU optimization that Metal can apply to texture data. Lossless compression reduces a texture’s memory size without discarding any of its data. On devices that support
, Metal attempts to apply lossless compression to a texture if it meets all of these conditions:
You don’t create the texture with a block-compressed pixel format, such as PVRTC, ASTC, or BC.
You don’t create the texture with an
, or
option.
You don’t create the texture from a buffer with the
method.
Additionally, if you meet both of the following conditions, you can optimize your texture data explicitly so Metal can apply lossless compression:
You create the texture with an
mode.
You write to the texture with the
or
method.
For guidance, see

content.text: Opt out of Texture Data Optimization for GPU Access

inlineContent.text: In some cases, your texture data may benefit from opting out of optimization for GPU access, for example, when optimization has regressed your app’s performance (particularly for render target read-backs on the CPU).
First, create a texture descriptor and set its
property to

code: // Don't allow the the GPU to optimize the texture.
// Don't allow the the GPU to optimize the texture.

inlineContent.text: Then, set the texture descriptor’s
property to
or

code: // Set the texture descriptor's storage mode to shared or managed based on the GPU family.
// Set the texture descriptor's storage mode to shared or managed based on the GPU family.

inlineContent.text: Finally, create a texture from the texture descriptor.

code: // Create a texture using the texture descriptor.
// Create a texture using the texture descriptor.

abstract.text: An object that creates textures from existing data in common image formats.
A specialized view that creates, configures, and displays Metal objects.
A Boolean value that determines whether the drawable’s textures are used only for rendering.
A false value.
A true value.
Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
Encodes a command that improves the performance of the CPU’s accesses to a texture.
Encodes a command that improves the performance of the CPU’s accesses to a specific portion of a texture.
Encodes a command that improves the performance of the GPU’s accesses to a texture.
Encodes a command that improves the performance of the GPU’s accesses to a specific portion of a texture.
Creates a texture that shares its storage with the buffer.
Represents the Apple family 5 GPU features that correspond to the Apple A12 GPUs.
The data formats that describe the organization and characteristics of individual pixels in a texture.
A texture handle that can be shared across process address space boundaries.
The CPU and GPU may maintain separate copies of the resource, and any changes must be explicitly synchronized.
The resource is only available to the GPU.
The CPU and GPU share access to the resource, allocated in system memory.
A resource that holds formatted image data.
Copies pixel data into a section of a texture slice.
Copies a block of pixels into a section of texture slice 0.
An object that you use to configure new Metal texture objects.
A Boolean value indicating whether the GPU is allowed to adjust the texture’s contents to improve GPU performance.
The location and access permissions of the texture.
An enumeration for the various options that determine how you can use a texture.
An option to create texture views with a different component layout.
An option for rendering to the texture in a render pass.
An option for writing to the texture in a shader.
An option for a texture whose usage is unknown.

abstract.text: Set a storage mode that defines the memory location and access permissions of a resource.
